sentence.text: The son of the proposita presented with a painful and swollen right leg and was easily fatigued.
At examination he showed no dysmorphic features and had a normal gait.
Initially, it was thought that his symptoms were caused by traumas, as he practiced kickboxing as a hobby.
Radiologically, in retrospect, the typical, symmetrical, cortical thickening of the diaphysis of the lower extremities was observed (Fig. 2).
He also showed sclerosis of the metacarpalia of the left hand.
The presence of radiologically confirmed bone abnormalities in the proposita (Fig. 1) as well as in her son (Fig. 2) suggested an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.
Consequently, we could rule out melorheostosis (which are mostly sporadic cases) as well as van Buchem’s disease (autosomal recessive inheritance) as possible diagnoses.
This led us to the diagnosis of Camurati–Engelmann Disease (CED).
